title: 114_hr3674
content: The "Labor Statistics Improvement Act" establishes the Commission to Improve Labor Statistics with specific duties. The Commission established by the "Labor Statistics Improvement Act" is tasked with examining the process of collecting and analyzing unemployment data by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. It includes assessing methods for determining job search activity and the effectiveness of reporting labor underutilization measures. The Commission will make recommendations for improving these processes and may propose alternative measures for labor force participation. The Commission established by the "Labor Statistics Improvement Act" is examining measures of labor force participation, considering factors like the official unemployment rate's accuracy, changes in labor force participation over the business cycle, the employment-to-population ratio, voluntary quits rate, and wage growth rates. The Commission is developing new methods to determine underemployment by considering workers not in jobs matching their skill set or education and those earning less than others in similar occupations. SEC. 4. MEMBERSHIP OF COMMISSION. The Commission shall consist of four members appointed by the President, two by the President pro tempore of the Senate, and two by the Speaker of the House of Representatives. Members must have expertise in economic analysis, labor markets, or statistical analysis. Appointments must be made within 90 days of the Act's enactment, and members serve for the Commission's lifetime. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members serve without basic pay but may receive travel expenses. The Commission members serve without pay but receive travel expenses. Six members constitute a quorum, and the Chairperson is elected by the members. Meetings are held at the Chairperson's call. SEC. 5. STAFF OF COMMISSION. The Chairperson appoints and determines staff pay. Staff appointments follow civil service laws. Federal agencies can provide personnel upon request. SEC. 6. REPORT OF COMMISSION. The Commission must submit a detailed report with findings and recommendations to the President and Congress within 180 days of all members being appointed. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting the report, during which it can conclude activities and provide testimony to Congress.
